Common respiratory viruses among HBoV infected children. in previous studies, none of the nasal swabs obtained from healthy children yielded a positive HBoV test. this suggests that HBoV is not a frequent commensal virus inhabiting the respiratory tract. in the current study, only one case was found to be infected only by HBoV as a single virus entity. most of isolates (17/18) showed coinfection with other viral pathogens. phylogenetic tree with 1,000 bootstrap replicates was generated using the Clustal W program in the MEGA 4.0 software package. samples obtained in the current study from children with acute respiratory distress in Saudi Arabia are in red. real-time PCR assay was performed using commercial, TaqMan hydrolysis probe based, real time PCR bocavirus detection kit. amplification reactions were performed in a volume of 25 l containing 2.5 l of DNA template, 21.5 l reaction mix, 0.4 l enzyme mix, 1 l internal control according to the manufacturer’s instructions. nucleotide sequences of the NS1 gene were compared with those of HBoV strains available at the GenBank site. the 3/18 partial sequences of the NS1 gene were submitted to GenBank.
